solution_line_template: If Eliza restocked twice the original number of ornamental rings, the number was {restocked_rings}/{multiplier}= <<{restocked_rings}/{multiplier}={original_stock}>>{original_stock} rings.
The total number of ornamental rings in stock is now {restocked_rings}+{original_stock} = <<{restocked_rings}+{original_stock}={total_initial_stock}>>{total_initial_stock} rings.

When she sells {sold_fraction} of the stock, the total number of rings sold is {sold_fraction}*{total_initial_stock} =<<{sold_fraction}*{total_initial_stock}={rings_sold_first_batch}>>{rings_sold_first_batch} rings.

When her mother buys {mother_buys} more rings, the stock is boosted to {remaining_stock_after_first_sale}+{mother_buys} = <<{remaining_stock_after_first_sale}+{mother_buys}={stock_after_mother_buys}>>{stock_after_mother_buys} rings.
She then sells out {second_sale}, reducing the stock to {stock_after_mother_buys}-{second_sale} = {final_remaining_stock} rings
